Date: July 5, 2015... Glassware: Schneider Edel Weisse large pokal... Occasion: July 4th lives on with USWNT in the finals vs. Japan--revenga! Appearance: an unfiltered, hazy, dark golden body allows bubbles to coalesce at the glasss base; a healthy two-finger sudsy white head that thins out consistently; glass displays no lacing as the beer sipping continues.... Aroma: banana, bubblegum, and the predominance of damp, flowery esters... Palate: effervescent and deceptively thin for 6+ ABV; highly drinkable, with a lingering, textured finish.... Taste: lemongrass, honey, and coriander make for a zesty buzz; more banana rears up late; nice, spicy sizzle of peppercorn at the throat... Overall: a formidable, reasonably full-flavored white that asserts malt strength to balance the flowery aspects of the ale; a crisp, refreshing wheat that has enough weight to satisfy an appetite... Found this at Wine Country in Htown and figured I would relive our 4th at Jers five years ago, at least through beer...

12 oz bottle into a pint glass.

A: Pours a hazy straw color with lots of chunky sediment. Theres about one fingers worth of white colored head. Both retention and lacing are pretty good.

S: Spicy. Theres a good amount of coriander, black pepper, sage, and orange peel, offset slightly by the sweet malts. Only detraction: the aroma seems oddly ham-like and smoky. For some reason, it reminds me of opening a can of Underwood deviled ham - this quality is really hard to shake off.

T: Luckily the flavor works better. Mild candied sugar combines with orange peel to start it off, and it finishes with plenty of coriander, sage, and other assorted garden herbs. Wheat flavors help bridge the opening with its clean, spicy finish. Theres a good combination of spicy and sweet here.

M: While it is a touch too sweet and a touch too flabby, the finish is pleasantly dry and the carbonation pokes through enough to help it go down well. It certainly hasnt lost much drinkability over its smaller brethren. 

O: I really get where they were going with this: its definitely bigger than the average wit, but not moronically so. Since this isnt a style that should be imperialized, it still works quite well (aroma notwithstanding). This would be really good in the summer weather, Ill just have to avoid smelling it next time I drink it.

12 ounce bottle into tulip glass, no bottle dating. Pours hazy and cloudy bright golden amber color with a 2 finger dense and fluffy white head with great retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Spotty foamy lacing clings on the glass. Aromas of big lemon zest, pear, orange zest, coriander, banana, clove, pepper, wheat, bread, floral, and yeast earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of yeast and spicing notes; with good strength. Taste of big lemon zest, pear, apple, orange zest, coriander, clove, banana, pepper, wheat, bread, floral, and yeast earthiness. Lingering notes of light fruits, citrus zest, coriander, banana, clove, wheat, pepper, bread, floral, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Awesome balance, robustness, and complexity of yeast ester and spice flavors; with a moderate malt balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium-high carbonation and medium bodied; with a very smooth, crisp, and lightly prickly mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is very well hidden with nearly zero warming present after the finish. Overall this is a fantastic witbier style! All around awesome complexity, balance, and robustness of yeast and spice flavors; and very smooth to drink. A highly enjoyable offering.

12 oz. bottle, pours a cloudy golden blond with a small white head. Nose is typical of a wit, with citrus, wheat, and a prominent coriander note. Flavour of sweet orange peel, some citrus, less of the coriander then on the nose, and wheat acting as the backbone. Finishes more so on the spicy / coriander notes, with some sweetness. Youve probably heard of "Double IPAs" but now a new niche style seems to be emerging - the "Double Witbier" which Im all for because I find regular witbiers to be a little too mild. But if youre going to "double" a witbier the outcome should be a little more impressive than a standard good beer, and thats what Southamptoon Double White is - a good witbier with a little more to it, but nothing amazing.

I poured a 12oz bottle into a tulip glass.

Appearance: White gold color, but opaque with haziness. Forms a small, white, soapy head which leaves minor lacing.

Smell: Orange and lemon pith but not "citrusy" per se. A touch of spice.

Taste: Mild fruit flavors up front. Since its brewed with orange lemon peel its not surprising it has a citrusy flavor to it, sans tartness and acidity. Little to no bitterness through the middle, but a touch of coriander spice. The finish is the best part with a remarkably sweet, almost candy-like taste of orange and lemon. Its basically the same palate youd get in any other brew of the style, just a bit more energy to it. Perhaps my bottle was old (and I wouldnt doubt it), but its all I have to go by. At least theres no dryness whatsoever, in fact its quite refreshing considering the style and bigger body than most. Tasty to be sure, but nothing in the ballpark of amazing.

Drinkability: Most witbiers brewed in the traditionally Belgian style tend to be low in weight and alcohol. Southamptoon Double White is a bit bigger at 6.6% ABV, but its just as easy to drink as the smaller beers. The body is thin, wet, and surprisingly tepid. Theres an almost watery texture to the body as well, but I wouldnt describe it as weak - just maybe a little too mild for its own good. I dont think any drinker of any experience level will have any trouble with this brew whatsoever.
Bottle at lucky lab. Pours clear yellow with a small head that quickly dissipates. Aroma is very spicy and has a good bit of lemon. Taste is pretty spicy with a nice citrus hit. Solid.
Hazy yellow pour with a modest head. Mild spice with a twist of orange citrus. Quite a nice refreshing summer drink.

Hazy golden body with a nearly nonexistent head. Loads of spice on the nose. Medium bodied with lifted orange zest, coriander and grainy components. A little white pepper on the finish. Complex and delicious.

Bottle...  Poured golden/yellow with a nice forming head.  Nice drinking wheat.  Dry and foamy palate.  Grassy, earthy, floral and spicy with a nice body. Banana phenols and fermented wheat malt notes added a nice complexity. Could drink this all day.

Warming, but overall impression was still quite light and crisp. So easy to drink it could get you in trouble, for sure.

On sample tap at southampton publick house.

hazy yellow color, aroma of coriander, lemon zest, wheat, bitter orange, flavors are the same, light body, slightly dry, lemon lingers, highly drinkable at 6.6%

Overall, this is an outstanding beer and I cant wait to pick up more...some to drink now and some to age a bit for the summer!

bottled. pours hazy golden yellow with a thin white head. aromas of orange, spice and grass. it is moderately sour. medium bodied , thick, with soft carbonation and a lasting sour finish.

Bottle. Pours hazy straw gold. Aroma is clove banana nutty, light body, taste is more clove and citrus lemon. Easy drinking and fearful, perfect representation of the style.

On tap at Brickyard in NYC. Aroma and appearance is standard-issue for american wheat-based ales - actually less cloudy than I expected. Taste is doughy with moderate fruity notes with a fairly crisp slightly toasted finish. Impressed given that this is the highest ABV white ale Ive ever seen.

Solid Belgian White, very crisp, clean, hoppy, you can taste the yeast as well but not as present as many other white ales.  Tastes almost like a pils to me but still a very solid beer and I was more than happy with it.
Pours clear gold with small white head.  Aroma is spicey pepper, citrus and some yeast.  Taste is citrus sweet with a tinge of tartness on the finish.
Bottle poured into shaker.  Smooth with cloudy yellow color.  Definite coriander and citrus.   A very good Belgian Wit and would love to drink more of these.

12 oz bottle from Half Time. Pours hazy pale gold with a foamy white head. Decent levels of orange and coriander aromas. Kind of mixed. Med body; foamy carbonation. I get a good dose of wheat and coriander, but I also get some great juicy orange notes. The alcohol is also fairly detectable in the beer. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Pretty good.

There wasnt much lacing of the head around the glass.  The nose was really funky, with some yeast, fruit, light hops and straw.  The body was fairly light, very drinkable and extremely refreshing.  The flavors were very well-balanced, with notes of bread, yeast, grass, light hops and a little bit of wheat.

Taste is wheat, slight yeastiness, and a touch of orange.  Slightly tart finish.  Good stuff, but maybe im just missing most of the spiciness of this.

Taste: tons of tart wheat, belgian yeast esters, a short note of corriander in the swallow, and some stale hop bitterness in the finish. The citrus is relatively imperceptible.

I like Sam Adams Imperial White Ale much better.

Highly carbonated sweet and tart flavor. Kindly taste like a white wine finish. Not bad but I prefer wittbier slightly less tart.
Pulled this out of a coo lee at the Hotel in upsate NY. Far better than expected. Smooth, tasty, perfect end to the evening.

Light and sweet aroma..definitely pick up the belgian yeast.   Extremely white but no haziness.  Sweet; neither hoppy nor malty particularly...a bit white wine-ish.  Belgian yeast finish.

Tap at Pony Bar. Pours a hazy, yellow-gold with a filmy white head. Lemon and citrus dominate the aroma with some mild malt notes. Somewhat floral. Flavor is sweet and light with light breadiness and some tart citrus. Despite the lightness, the flavor is rich. Medium in body with fizzy carbonation. Finishes sharp and lightly sweet. Very good.
Had this wit on draft at a beer bar in the East Village. Delicious, clean subtle flavors, very drinkable.

Flavor is tart orange, spices, yeast, and a tart cherry and sour grape finish.  Medium carbonation, a little sour, and a touch spicy.  Very nice.  Tart orangey and wheaty beer, and pretty refreshing.

12 oz bottle. Pours a clear yellow with a thin layer of white bubbles that dissapear quickly. Aroma is  huge here: banana, coriander, orange peel, yeast , sweet with some spice. Taste is a little on the sweet side. Somewhat complex flavors, sweet and fruity. All the aromas are evident in the taste. Smooth, almost creamy mouthfeel with a quick spicy bitterness in the finish.

Hazy golden yellow with a medium white head with solar flare lacing.  Aroma of heavy yeast, coriander, orange, pepper, fruit and bready malt.  If they mean double in terms of aroma  they are dead on as this is one of the most inviting wit biers Ive come across.  Body seems fuller than most witbiers too and smooth to boot.  Taste of coriander and orange, fruity yeast and a touch of pepper and citrus.  Lively mouth feel in a tasty package.  Nicely done.

12oz bottle.  Pours a translucent golden yellow color with a lively, fizzy look.  A good covering of bubbles that quickly disappeared was all I saw for the head.  Aroma is sweet and grassy, very pleasant.  Taste is sweet with a good orange peel and spice flavor.  Nothing overpowering and I like it.  Great medium bodied wit.

Cloudy cream yellow pour, with nice white head.  Sweetness, orange peel, wheat, lemon, hay, spice (clove and coriander), and a bit of banana.  Actually a really nice wit, I enjoyed it.  Bottle many thanks to Beerman6686.
Pours pretty clear, golden. Aroma is heavy with esters, orange peel... Drinks lit a wit, but the extra booze eliminates the refreshing quality.

On tap at Rattle N Hum in NYC. Pours pale yellow, large white head. Unfiltered-ness reveals yeast floaters.  Aroma of bananas and cloves. Fruity flavor prevails. Nice smoothness and carbonation create a nice mouth-feel. 6.6% is perfect for a hot summer day with nothing else to do. Enjoyable beer, especially for $5.
12oz bottle.  Pretty true to style as far as taste but not sure if the higher ABV is a great idea. Pours a cloudy golden color. Predominant taste is coriander.
Bottled version. The appearance is flat with a cloudy light yellow color. Aroma is on the pungent side. Flavor is way too spicy for my liking. Body is a bit heavy too. I will stick with Hoe.
Tap at Busboys & Poets.  Hazy orange color.  Aroma of orange.  Taste of orange.  Not  much more than that, actually.

Poured in Sam Adams Sensory Glass.

Color is a straw pale yellow. Head is really thin light yellow. Fizzles down quickly, but leaves a little lace. Flakey things are floating around in it. Wheat maybe? It didnt taste old at all so I have no idea...

Smell is of bananas and cloves. Very fruity aroma. Taste is quite similiar, very strong on the fruit notes.

Mouthfeel is very great. So smooth at the beginning and then I slight note of bitterness at the end.

Overall, this is a great beer and I really enjoyed it. I would definately recommend it.

This is what a witbier should be. Cloudy orange, fluffy white head, prominent citrus aroma. Great light body, but heavy enough. Clean finish. Tons of coriander. Awesome.

12 oz bottle. Pours a nice hazy pale orange with a small white head. Aroma is very sweet and mellow citric. Very overripe orange, as the citric is almost creamy and not sharp. Very heavy wheat and a slight spiciness. Flavor starts creamy and citric but picks up a sharp zest before a more forthcoming spice note. Ends softly bitter and the wheat comes forward more astringently. Medium spritzy body and a sharper carbonation. Really refreshing, nice wit, hides the relative high abv very well and nice complexity along with the softness.

Pours pale golden and hazy with a miniscule head and no lacing.  Aroma is semi-sweet, citric and yeasty. Flavor is subtle but well balanced consisting of citrus, yeast, and spices.  Tangy full finish.

On Tap at Mr. Beerys in Sarasota. Pours pale hazy gold with thin white head. The aroma is full with grainy malts and wheat as well as some pepper and a touch of sweet banana. The taste is similar going from assertive wheat and grains and then quickly into a thin layer of pepper. By about midway and to the finish banana wheat and apple sweetness take the experience home.
This is a not a beer I would go out of my way to try again. Tried at a beer festival. Most people had good things to say about it, but I found it to be a little flat in flavor.

Bottle. Hazy light gold, nice head. Very fruity aroma. It is in fact a bit rich for a Wit. The fruit is mostly orange peel and banana. I dont get much tartness from it. Tasty, but I think it sacrifices some refreshment in the process.

When you put "double" before white ale, I am always going to be skeptical. Why  increase the gravity of a brew thats chief strength is that its a summertime thirst quencher?  It pours cloudy golden orange but maybe not quite cloudy enough for the style--and I poured in every last drop from the bottle--w/ a small head that fades fast and is made of large mixed sized bubbles to begin w/. To be completely earnest, there is nothing about the appearance of this beer that makes me want to drink it. The nose, on the other hand, does well enough in its own mild way. A bit of banana and clove yeast character dance around some bright orange peel notes. The alcohol is noticeable which I feel is a pretty big negative on a beer thats in this strength range but it tastes decent otherwise. Mouthfeel is light and lacking in the thick wheaty, soft carbonated texture in the best of the style. This is just one of those beers that theres nothing really wrong w/ thats just not really good. There is no reason for a beer w/ this much flavor to be above 4-5% ABV and as such I feel like Southampton failed in doing what they were trying to do.

Pours a cloudy yellow with 1" thick head that slowly dissipates to a thin film, leaving solid lacing on the glass.  Aroma is classic witbier with wheat, pale malts, and lemon zest.   Some sweet and peppery notes.  Taste is malty bread with lemon and orange.  Very nice spice on the finish.  There is a lot of flavor in this one. Light bodied, dry finish, and easy to drink.  Very good summer brew.
Cloudy yellow. Wonderful crisp taste of citrus and spice. Very crisp finish.

Appearance:  Pours a bright cloudy yellow with a 1/8 inch layer of white film.

Aroma:  Bread dough, citrus, banana and light spice.

Taste:  Orange banana juice with a slightly spicy finish with a touch of bread crust.

Mouthfeel: Medium bodied and fizzy.

Overall:  A very bold fruity wheat beer. I am glad this wasnt all thick and syrupy like Samuel Adams Imperial White.  Really quite drinkable for a style I wouldnt go after.

A- Uniform hazy yellow body with thin foamy white head. Head eventually fades and leaves behind little lacing in the glass. The translucent cloudy body is well done and shows that the brew is unfiltered.

S- Slightly sour citrus with accents of yeast, coriander, and other spices.

T- Great balance of wheat, sour citrus, and spices upfront. Some hoppiness then kicks in with yeast and spice. Yeast and sour citrus linger on the palate.

P- Light yeasty body and medium carbonation. Goes down easy.

O- I was really excited to finally get to try this brew. Its delicious-but a bit on the sour side for a witbier. The ABV is completely masked here-it tastes like a normal session ale. I will have this one again.

Serving type: bottle

On tap at Underground Bluz. After too many IPAs and stouts, I needed some relief. I found it in the Double White. Hazy yellow, small white head. Great aroma - lots of spice, yeast, and even a touch of alcohol. Finally a full-flavored Wit. Maybe thats why its called a "double wit.". Really balanced well - spices, yeast, citrus, light carbonated body - all come together really well for the style. Dry finish. Really good.
bottle, pours hazy gold with a thin white head.  Aroma is strong coriander and citrus.  Flavor is strong wheat and coriander with a peppery finish.  Lingering citrus in the finish as well.

Bomber, about 1 ½ years old. Golden color like a pils, with almost no head. Spicy, tangy aroma with light horse blanket. Flavors of sour lemon candy, ginger ale, orange. Really quite sourfrom its age? But tart and refreshing. Interesting and nice enough but a bit weird.

has a nice white pillow of a head and good lacing. aroma and flavor is light banana, orange peel, and corriandor. has a medium body and good carbonation for a wit. nice  and smooth and pretty strong. it is pretty good.

Serving: On draft at Fireworks.
It pours a dark yellow color with a foamy, white head.  The nose light with slight touches of lemon and grapefruit.  The taste is much milder than I was hoping for as well.  A little lemon, grapefruit, banana and spice.  Very underwhelming.  Light mouthfeel with low carbonation and a short finish.  Just not that good and not worth recommending.

Pours hazy yellow orange with an off white head.  Aroma is light and wheaty, with some spice and citrus aroma coming through.  Flavor is light and wheat malts, with a little bit of banana, hints of coriander and other spices, and a little bit of light candied fruit at the end.  Pretty good.
Bottle. The honey sweetness in this beers drowns everything else and turns it into a one-dimensional, quite boring thing. Still drinkable though.

Bottle at Sweet Afton. Pours golden yellow with standard white head. Aroma is hefe-like with banana, wheat, coriander and black pepper. Flavor again has banana, but more malt and yeast emerge. Theres also a subtle sour flavor I cant decipher that complements everything rather nicely. Theres a slight wheat finish, but its more one-dimensional than I was expecting or hoping for.

(Bottle, Monks Café Wallingatan, Stockholm) Golden yellow colour, slightly hazy, with frothy white head. Fruity, malty nose with wheat flour dough, citrus, grass and tropical fruit. Malty, slightly fruity taste with notes of citrus, pineapple and a doughy wheat character. More than medium body, with solid malt structure. Balanced sweetness. Short citrussy finish with low bitterness. Solid and tasty witbier.
excellent wit beer. 22 oz on tap. even more flavorful than most other wits I have tried. very yeasty taste and smell.

On draft at Capones.  Pour is a hazy gold with a thick foamy white head.  Nose coriander, light orange rinds, and old vegetables.  Taste is yeast, light caramel malt, coriander, and a very light vegetable funk.  I actually enjoyed this Wit more than usual.  It is not as strong in the citrus and old vegetables like many Wits, and the malt is also stepped up a notch.  Definitely drinkable and whats better, somewhat enjoyable!
Bottle. Very light pour with minimal head. Aroma and taste of orange and coriander. More body than the appearance would suggest. Nice brew.
On tap at Capones. Light and cloying head. Taste is very light considering the ABV. This one could sneak up on you. Very good Belgian wheat beer. This is like a Hoegaarden big brother.

Since my car broke down I had to walk a mile to Stop and Shop to get supplies and picked up a six pack of this brew which they dont normally carry.  Pours hazy yellow with very little head that dissapears quickly.  tastes citrusy and you can pick out the orange peel.  Very refreshing and and enjoyable beer and well worth carrying a mile uphill in 35 degree weather.
On Draft at Capones.  LIght clove aroma, hazy yellow body with thin head... light wheat and spice flavor, hints of cloves and orange... bready aftertaste

Poured from a 12oz bottle, the color is a golden/pale yellow. Aroma is a mix of citrus and lemongrass. Appearance is pretty common, with a head that diminishes quickly but the carbonation bubbles leave it active the entire time drinking it.  In taste, it hits you with a medium sweetness and a light sourness at the end of each sip. The beer itself is medium to light with a slight oily texture and with an overall average carbonation  and slight astringent finish. Overall, for it currently being in the top 10 (as of this review) of the Witbier it was good and actually is a bit more complex then most and strays to slight variations in ingredients which give the beer its own uniqueness. The use of the Curacao orange peel is what sets it apart (in my own opinion) with the fact that the oranges already have a heavy sour bitterness that even standard bitter oranges rarely match.
bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  hazy pale yellow with a white head.  nose is wheat, fruits and not much else.  decent on the palate with a typical flavor for a wit, wheat, fruits, and a clean finish.
Bottle from Thirdeye11.  Extremely pale yellow pour.   Aroma is lots of banana, clove, and honey.  Taste is floral, coriander, and honey.
Bottle courtesy of thirdeye11. Light straw pour. Spicy oleander smell with gentle stinging spice. Easy mouthfeel. Sweet flavors that turn into awesomeness.
Great beer. On draft. Lots of spicyness with the right amount of body. Medium bodied. Some floral hops, light malts, and some yeast.  Well balanced. Lightly bitter finish. My ideal witbier.

Pours a yellow color and not much cloudiness to it with a small white head. Nose is full of yeast and some citrus and spice notes. Nice medium body and the flavors are banana, coriander, some orange flavors sweetness to it as well. An easy drinking and enjoyable beer.

12oz bottle poured into a Weizen glass at 50°.  Color is a hazy light yellow with good carbonation and a small white head.  Aroma of citrus, spice and yeast.  Its a medium bodied brew with a smooth mouth feel and a finish of orange, nutmeg and coriander with a yeasty banana taste on the end.  Overall its a tasty brew but I was expecting it to be a little bolder being a double White.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2010 (Draught at Falling Rock Tap House) light colored as true to style, 1/2 finger head that lingers well, minimal lacing and only slighty opaque. Nose smells funky like a saison! Coriander, celery, grapes, a vinegary sour up front, Florals, mild citrus. Taste is overwhelmingly white wine like sour grapes, but I really like it. Also spices and citrus that lingers. Never bitter and very refreshing. A top witbier for sure.
Bottle. Golden colour with a white head. Aroma is sour, citrus, wheat, fruit. Flavour is sour, citrus, wheat, mandarin. Medium body. OK beer.

Bottle, 12oz. Its an almost clear, almost golden beer topped by a minimal off-white head. Slightly peppery on the nose, with sourish citrusy notes. Nice, bud it could be more pronounced. The flavor is more on the curacao orange side than I prefer, both sweet and slightly sour, with appropriate coriander levels. Herbal, bitter finish. Medium body. A refreshing beer, pity the flavor isnt at the same level as the aroma. 090925

12 oz Bottle -- Pours hazy gold with a thin white head.  Subdued and tight nose, pleasant but nothing special.  Bitter orange, hay, and some spice.  Nice and spicey with a good bitter back-end for a white ale.

12oz bottle.  Poured a cloudy yellow color with a big white head that evaporates almost immediately.  The aroma has a strong backbone of spices and corriander with a hint of citrus. The corriander and spice character continues in the flavor with a lemony citrus in the bacground.  Very light bodied and smooth with a great drinkability.
Very refreshing.  Balanced Citrus flavor.  A bit too carbonated for me.  Well rounded.
Pours a pale yellow with a small white head.  Aroma of coriander and a hint of citrus.  Flavor matches the aroma. Decent beer.
Clear yellow, filtered, thick creamy looking white head.  Standard aroma for the style, coriander and citrus.  Nice full banana palate with a touch of orange.  Decent, not great.

Clean straw blonde body with a light head. Nice coriander and light orange aromas. However the flavor demonstrates considerably more robustness. Strong coriander and orange peel across a full wheaty body. Much more agressive than its Belgian Witt brethren.

22 oz. bottle from moejuck - thanks Joe! I wasnt too excited about this one for some reason, but man did it sneak up on me. Poured hazy copper with a white head. Smell is white grapes, tangy orange juice, overripe cantaloupe, and yeast. The orange really comes through in the taste, along with pear, a bit of blueberry, some typical Belgian spicing, and a nice hop finish. Tastes light but the body has some heft to it. Overall, fruity, tasty, and pretty refreshing.
12oz - Brassy, cloudy pour with a 1/4" white head.  Nice lace throughout.  Watery feel with a spicy palate.  Some hops at the finish.  A good, solid white, comparable to Hoegaarden
Nice Corriander scent and taste. Light and still refreshing and bold. Nice white head. very smooth and complex.

12 oz bottle. Pours a cloudy pale yellow with a small white head. Not an attractive beer. Spicy citrus nose with grain. Nice, easy drinking palate with a bit of tongue tingle. Rich wheat based flavor, jazzed up with Belgian yeast and citrus notes of orange peel and lemon zest.

The look is very thick and cloudy. Bright sunny yellow. No head but that may be my own fault. Looks sunny and refreshing.

Some spciy orange peel in the nose. Mild wheat base. Smell is mild overall but orange and Belgian spices dominate.

The taste has a spicy initial burst, then a more sweetish fruity flavor. As it warms, a pleasant puckery sour flavor comes out. Strong Belgian Ale spices; halfway between a Belgian ale and a witbier. Quite pleasant.

Feels fizzy but smooth. Juice-like feel on the way down. A nice spicy-sweet Belgian white ale. Easy drinking with a small bite.

Bottle.  Pours a bright but hazy golden with very thin whtie head.  Very faint aroma, mostly wheat with a little bit of peach.  Flavor is wheat with an underlying citrus orange mixed with apparent corriander and other spices, very dry, finishes bitter.  Very light on the palate, easy to drink.  Good, definitely worth a try.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a hazy yellow gold with fizzy white head.  Smells of fruity wheat, clementine, apricot.  Sweet yeasty taste with fruity notes on finish.  Maybe Im just not into this style right now, but i dont see why this one is so good - not that its bad or anything, very drinkable and tasty, just not anything extraordinary to me.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a hazy dark yellow with a smallish white head that that quickly diminishes and leaves some lacing.

The aroma is spices, funky yeast, some banana and clove and some fruits.

The flavor is sweet lemony fruits and wheaty malts with a little yeastiness and some spices and soapiness.  The mouthfeel is light bodied and slightly watery with spritzy carbonation.

Overall, a decent wit.  I tend to like them sweet and fruity.

really nice belgian white. i compare most to alagash, and this one was right up there. not bad spice content, not enough to contend w/ alagash, but decent. nice clean aftertase that warrants many more drinks.

Draft at redlight redlight.  Pours a light golden yellow.  The nose is full of orange peel and coriander.  Very floral.  Lots of wheat in the flavor.  An extra punch to the tradition Belgian white.  Still crisp and refreshing.  Good for summertime.  Not boring at all.

12 oz bottle. Livly, golden body with a diminishing whitehead. Aroma is spicy and slightly acid with a hint of esters. Flavor is sweet with some fruity acid, spices and mandarin. Refreshing, some bitterness in the finish, a bit thin body and short aftertaste.

12oz bottle served in a shaker.  Hazy golden orange pour with a thin off-white film for a head.  Minimal lacing.  The aroma had wheat, orange, coriander, and also some spicy/clovey yeast.  The flavor was crisp and had notes of fresh wheat, bright orange, coriander, bread dough, and also some spicy yeast.  Pretty nice.  The palate was medium-bodied and had a light amount of crisp, lively carbonation.  A really nice example of the style.

Clear golden body; chunky white head.  Aroma of orange peel and banana.  Strong coriander and yeast in the flavor, with a solid hoppiness (style considering).  Alcohol not really apparent.  I wouldnt call it a Double in the sense of an IIPA, but its a great Wit for those who enjoy assertive beers.

12oz bottle.  A little bummed this didnt come in the 750 corked and caged bottle like the one pictured.  Pours a lightly hazed golden yellow with a frothy white head, nice lacing.  A ton of coriander on the nose as well as lemon peel.  Flavor was light and quite tangy, lots of citrus peel and coriander.

On tap at Independents Day 2009 on 9/19/2009; it was either this or PBR, but it was a pleasant surprise; I guess a plastic cup is a poor substitute for a tumbler or weizen glass, but the quality of the ale overcame such a humble vessel; I wasnt alone in this assessment, for the two beer wagons ran out around 7pm.

12oz bottle - Pours clear yellow/gold with a very thin head.  It has a spicy aroma of coriander and clover with citrus notes as well.  The flavor is sweet and spicy with some citrus.  Its medium bodied and leaves a touch of coriander in the finish.  Very solid.

12oz bottle.  Pours hazy gold with a decent white head.  Smells of lemons, spices, and wheat.  Tastes of lemon zest, candy sugar, carriander, wheat, and pear.  Very nice creamy mouthfeel, nice body, and long sweet aftertaste.  Pretty good brew.

BPW #22
12 oz bottle picked up at FUBOBs. Appearance is sunshine gold. The nose on this one is full of Belgium yeasts with a holiday spice to it. Flavors follow with a spiced holiday cookie flavor profile.

Dans Bachelor Party Extended Weekend Rating #21 of 90. Bottle Dan picked up at parti pak while out here (thanks). Pours yellow gold with white head. Good belgian nose with a dose of orange peel. Flavor has a excellent orange character. Some wheat and citrus, very refreshing. Not bad.

Pours a light golden yellow with a bright fizzy white head, which is typical of a Belgian style white ale. The smell is of grains, citrus, and coriander. The taste is much stronger and more pronounded than the typical white ale. The beer balances the delicate taste of the grains, with the orange zest and coriander seed. This is one of the best white ales that I have had.

Bottle pour.Light orange color with a decent head.Aroma was orange and spice with some wheatiness.Flavor was spicy with citrus undertones.Nice malt flavor in there as well,some hop hints too.Moderate smoothness but not too harsh.Very good.
Cloudy golden ale with a soft, thin white head, a little sour-smelling, needs more orange to overcome the sour taste.
A golden beer with a 1 finger head. Aroma of spices, & banana. The taste is spicy & reminds me of a Hefe.

Bottle:  Pours a very light yellow with no head...nose is massive, loads of lemon rind, orange rind, coriander and some other unidentifiable spices.  Medium bodied...quite silky on the mouth.  Flavor is everything that was present in the nose with an emphasis on the coriander seed, it really comes through on the finish.  Very good brew.

Very nice cloudy yellow with a small head that laces the glass. Aroma is spices and citrus maybe orange peal. Flavor has the spice and orange with a very nice sour bite. Finishes very dry and crisp. Give me another.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2010 New rating from a good bottle; see my old rating below.  A nice baby Belgian, good if youre new to craft or new to Belgians.  Nose and taste is very lemony.  A little of that Belgian yeast taste, but not too much.  An extremely drinkable beer; goes down almost like water.  Enjoy one!

I really hate to do this because I probably got a bad bottle... but here goes.  12 oz bottle which poured with no head.  The taste was syrupy with hints of wheat but no discernable undertones or flavors, most likely due to the lack of carbonation.  Drain pour.  If I ever come upon another bottle, Ill buy it and re-rate but until then, I thought this beer was lousy.  I am a big fan of Southamptons "single" white.

Was in my cooler when I got home from a tasteing. Good lmix of aromas wheat grain, lemon and some coriander. Yellow body with white head. Good citric acid carbination with some lemon zest and dry citrus peel in the mix. Good refreshment.
This delicious white ale pours cloudy yellow with a solid head. It is spicy and has the classic white ale flavor in the tradition of Belgian whites.

[Bottle] Pours a hazy yellow color with plenty of fluffy white head. Aroma of citrus, grain and grass. Coriander and spice blend with the wheat malt in the taste. Light citrus finish. You could tell this was a little stronger than your typical Wit, but I think that took away from this beers potential. Everything didnt quite add up for me. An inoffensive and very drinkable beer. Ive certainly had better examples of the style though.

Picked up on a trip to Texas.  Nice example of a Belgian White, but when I saw the word "double" I guess was was expecting something new and different. Should have checked on this more in advance. Good stuff, though... sweet, spicy, funky, orangey. Whatd you expect?

Wit beers are an equal favorite for me in comparison to German Weise/Hefeweizen beers. As a beer style, they are incongruous with summer, sunshine, warm weather, and thirst quenching session beers. No beer style better represents thirst-quenching refreshment better than a Belgian Wit or German Hefe. The folks at Southampton Publick House know this and have crafted the Double Wit, a Belgian Wit that rivals Hooegarden in its richer spiced approach loaded with mouth-watering refreshment.


Cloudy, hazy, and crowned with a soft tuft of white foam which lingers as a thick blanket. Her colors are blanched hay and straw with a soft white haze floating about her person. Nothing could hold her nose back as wave after wave of mouth-watering coriander; clove, bananas and cream, lemon zest, kiwi, and kneading dough fill my senses. A wisp of hay, barnyard dust, and saddlebags linger in the background. I could smell her nose all day long, but then I would be missing out on what lingers below. Thick, full, and chewy with soft bread dough and a puree of bananas, cream, clove, coriander, and orange peel glide effortlessly over my tastebuds. Lemon zest lingers in my breath which compliments her light finish. She is rich and full up front and in the middle, but fades softly into her finish for a balance that is highly refreshing and thirst-quenching. A bit more banana than I was expecting for a Belgian Wit, but she is a double wit and when one keeps in mind the flavor-explosion that is Hooegarden, one can see the parallels. A faint dryness starts to grow, hinting of bailed hay, barnyard dust, and saddlebags, but then her spiced, creamy banana and zesty palate kicks it into high gear once more. It must have been on the warmer side in my apartment because my Double Wit is long gone; all that lingers are tantalizing clumps of puffy white lace and foam.


Rich, expressive, exciting, packed with flavor, and still super easy to drink. A winner on all accounts in my book. Up until recently, I had only heard of the classic quality and skills that went into Southamptons special beers, but now I understand. Their Double Wit could have been too much double of everything, but instead, an amazing balance was achieved and I found another great thirst-quencher to get me through the long, hot Florida summer months.

Pours a hazy, creamy, white with a medium whitie fluffy head.  Aroma is fruity, citrusy, slightly spicey, and earthy.  Drinks very light and crisp with notes of orange, corriander, banana, lemon, earthiness, grass, and Belgian yeast.  A very solid white ale.  Been seeing this on tap a lot around Orlando lately.  A great beer for summer, very refreshing, do recommend!

Bottle in tumbler glass. Pours a slightly hazy yellow/gold body with a very thin bubbly white head. Musky, yeasty aroma with some wheat notes. Nicely carbonated wheat and grassy flavor. Refreshing average witbier. I was expecting a lot more out of this beer.

Pours a hazy honey color with a nice amount of yellowish head.  Earthy aroma of malt and bananas with a lot of spice.  Flavor is very sweet--fruity, with coriander and some clove.  A slightly bitter aftertaste.  Pretty good.

Bottle and draft.  I had 4 imperial pints and then ate popcorn till i felt sick, ill never forget that time, still gives me the chills.  A hazy orange golden body with a white head.  Coriander, wheat, bubblegum and spices.  Sweet but slightly grain y.   Decent.

Bottle via the rip and run and the fella pushing the Southampton tasting.  Light nose of citrus and faint touches of corrienader and clove.  Not much else in the nose.  Bosy is medium minus and surpisingly creamy. I was expecting the normal lackluster watery body that is passed for a wit.  A nice hazy yellow with a lazy carbonation and thin head.  This dows not sneak up on you buyt rather tells ou rateher bluntly (go New York) that you are about to be a bit tipsy. Aroma is heavy malt (husky grain, cereal, meal), average hop (grass, perfume), heavy yeast (dough) with notes of orange, creamed corn, alcohol, and coriander.  Light bodied, oily texture, average carbonation, and a bitter-spicy finish.  Average duration, light sweetness, moderate acidity and bitterness.

From the Bottle at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 11/10/2007
Small white head. Amber coloured and slightly hazy in appearance. Banana fruit flavour. Crisp and bitter finish.
Pours a pale gold with a white head that sticks around.  Aroma is lots of coriander and orange.  Taste is very sweet, coriander, orange, yeast.  Easy drinking, and a good summer beer.

Tap @ Just Jakes. One of only three "craft" beers on tap. Wasnt sure how this would be. Wheat and fruit ester fueled aroma. Flavor was of citrus and spices however beer was not too sweet. Nice witbier.

A very nice version of one of my favorite styles of beer.  This beer is loaded with orange and coriander and has a very fresh malty body to accompany all that flavor and spice near the end.  Very cloudy with a wonderful aroma of citrus and spice.  A very good beer.
Bottle.  Hazy yellow pour with a small white head that quickly disapears.  Aroma of bananas and cloves is a bit faint.  Taste is much stronger, very pronounced Belgian flavor.  Very good.

12 oz. bottle. Picked up at Macs on West Peachtree. Nice looking wit. Nice dark haze yellow beer. Very thin head that fades away eventually. Looks pretty good to me. Very sweet aroma.
