The palate is not as thick as I was worried it was going to be based on the pour, instead it is crisp lighlt prickly with not too much heft to it. Overall a very nice beer, one that I was doubting would be any good but surprised me.
Very Spicy and Citrusy!!  aroma of lemon, herbs, and resin.  Appearance is a cloudy golden orange, Has a medium sweetness, but the spices man --- the SPICES are what does it.

This bottled brew sampled at Dicks Bodacious Bar-B-Que RB event poured a foamy head of white colored finely sized mostly lasting bubbles that left a body of very hazy orange brown color.  The aroma was mild with spicy malty notes.  The mouth feel was softly tingly and pretty much flat from start to finish.  The flavor was mildly fruity and doughy.

Bottle. Small white head that quickly dissipated, no lacing, cloudy, and a straw yellow hue. Oranges, citrus, some spice notes and sweet nose. Flavor was sweet, oranges and citrus. Smooth palate. Light-medium body.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2007 12 oz. bottle sampled 6/26/2007. I wonder if my tastes have changed or if perhaps this was a fresher bottle (it had just arrived from the distributor). Hazy light honey color with a moderate white head.  Aroma is both sour and sweet with plenty of citrus. More aromatic than I remember.  Plenty of citrus in the flavor as well, although I get more lemon than orange.  Even though this is labelled a winter brew, I found it very refreshing on a warm summers evening.

22 oz. bottle. The Publick House has updated their packaging from the photo provided with this listing. Pours a cloudy, honey color with a thin head. Light, sweet, citrus aroma. Flavor is sweet grass and citrus with some hops bitterness at the finish. Refreshing beer. Original rating: 6,3,7,4,14=3.4.

Sample at Indy tasting Dicks BBQ 3/31/06 - Aroma is banana, citrus, yeast, and candi sugar.  Pours cloudy yellow with small head and no lacing.  Flavor matches aroma.  Palate is clean and crisp.  Not bad.

22oz bottle via trade with goldtwins - Thanks Larry! - Poured cloudy golden with not much head.  Aromas of yeast, corriander, orange peels, and lemon.  Flavor is yeast, corriander, lemon, orange, and some cloves.  Palate is light but not carbonated much.  Easy to drink and the bitter finish keeps you coming back for another sip.  Pretty well in form with the other Southampton brews Ive had..  Tasty!

The fourth brew to please my palate.  Were still on the light side of life.  This yellow-green ale was full of coriander with a citrus-peel bitter finish.  A lot of clove in this one.  Lighter than the alcohol content would lead you to believe.  This could please in summer as well as winter.

Courtesy of Shadey

Nose is spicy and lemony with a good bit of malt base. Light gold/yellow in color with a firm white thumb thick head. Fore is malty sweet with lots iof wheaty/grainy notes, but it never gets allt he way formed as a bitter lemon peel/citric flavor always rushes in right as you start to explore that sweet malt side. Very bready at times. Very bitter lemon zest tasting at others. Quite refreshing yet also hearty and filling.
Pours cloudy and pale, with a hint of amber.  Nice white head.  Nose is of spices, bubblegum, wheat and other sweet malts.  Flavor is the same.  Nicely balanced, fairly dry finish.
Really not bad!  A richly alcoholic bodied, lots of malt, wheat/hay with the perfect amount of corriander, some brown sugar, leading to a lemony dry finish.  Very nice.

Pale golden color. Heavy corriander aroma with some sweet malts and orange coming through also. Flavor is also heavy on the corriander, light sweetness, some bready malts, and light citrus fruits in the finish. Good, but a little too focused on the corriander for my tastes.
Hazy Orange with a brilliant white head.  Nice sents of corriander almost immediatly with notes of citrus and orange. flavor was yeasty citrusy and light spice. Very Nice Beer

Poured a soft creamy orange creamsicile color and left a pillow white head that laced the Wheat glass I was drinking from. The smell was sweet dew, canteloupe, melons, were very present in the nose of this brew. A slight hoppy presence was detected as I breathed through my mouth. The appearance of this brew is very cloudy due to the unfiltered process but makes the body look mysterious and inviting. As I tasted this ale the wheat flavors massaged my palate and the sweetness from the honey, and spice flavors from what tastes like cloves, orange peels, and a hint of vanilla all give this ale a fantastic finish.

Definitely a coriander bomb.  The stuff was all over this beer - soapy in the nose, soapy in the taste, soapy in the finish.  The body was moderately thick - and it looked pretty damn good - but lay off the coariander and orange peel a little bit.  I know its the whole "double white" thing, but consider keeping the spices level and just doubling the hops and malts, make it more like a slightly-more-spiced tripel.  Oh well.  It was drinkable, but too over the top.

Aroma:  spices, light honey, coriander, light wheat

Appearance:  murky golden yellow, small head, little lacing

Flavor:  slight soapy, wheat, spices/coriander

Palate:  smooth, little soapy; nice light wheaty/coriander finish

Overall:  doesnt taste, feel, or smell any different than a regular well-made wit beer...hmm...

Cloudy orange/yellow, big white head, nice lacing.  Nose was malty sweet with and equal helping of citrus and spice.  Lemon edges but probably more malt/wheat body than expected (I guess thats the double part).  A little heavy for all of the fruity sweetness

Tasted at Belgium Comes to Cooperstown, July 16, 2005.  Hazy blonde with a thin white head. Light bubble gum wheat in aroma. Hoegarden like bubble gum taste, with lemon notes, and sharp alcohol. Medium bodied.

Bottle - sampled at the RBESP 2005
Coudy yellow, white head.
Citric aroma and fruity mellow citrus flavoring. Fairly lightbodied. Didnt stand out in the extreme lineup of the summerparty, would love to try it again.

750 bottle, thanks to eyedrinkale for the trade.  Pours light amber with a slight haze and a moderate white head.  Aroma features niice fruity malts, with lots of yeasty notes.  Flavor is heavily citrus, with spicy breadiness and a good bitter finish.  Light to medium body with assertive carbonation.  Very nice with dinner - thanks Mike.

This one seemed to pack a punch with fine wheat beer qualities of coriander and fruit (lemon and orange) along with a mouthfeel which was effervescent. The alcohol content definately makes a stand with this one. Taste-wise it could have used a bit more but its a great beer as far as palatte, aroma, and balance are concerned.
Cloudy yellow/golden hue with a light white head.  Aromas of wheat, light spice, honey and a light banana.Flavors of buttery lemon, a light sour bite and a fruit loopy finish.  Very effervescent.

Hazy yellow-orange body, thin-medium off-white head.  Aroma of pear, honey, flower nectar, tangy wheat, and spice (coriander).  Tangy wheat body with plenty of coriander and peppery notes, typical for the style.  Medium-bodied, quite spicy.  Above average.  Thanks Dan (jah noth) for the trade!
Spicy aroma, clove, corriander.  Pours a golden blonde.  Everything you could want in a Double Wit!

courtesy of silphium.....hazy orangish-yellow body with minimal head....aroma typical of a belgian wheat/whit, and is of citrus notes (heavy on orange)....flavor is of orange peel and starfruit skin, and has quite a spiciness to it....nice palate

Bottled: Pours a cloudy golden body with almost no head. Aroma is citrus - lemons and oranges and also quite spicy. Flavor is the same. Theres quite a bit of bite here, but somehow it feels slightly watery. Cool idea, I think it worked well.

Thanks to the ratebeerian who sent this my way. Sorry I dont remember. Golden yellow with decent white head. Nice yeasty/banana aroma with some spice in the background. Flavor much the same with a citrus sweetness on top of the banana. Very lively carbonation and mouthfeel. Nicely done, very enjoyable.
Pours with a muddy golden body topped by a thin to medium thick head with little lacing.  Its slightly sweet, yeasty and lemony with a slight spiciness.  Light to medium bodied, crisp and tingly.

Pours out a very nice cloudy golden straw color with good carbonation. The head is small, thin and white. Taste is very smooth with some good spice and wheat and some notes of citrus. I liked this one!

Bomber.  Aroma strong citric, orange and lemon with belgian yeast notes.  Pour is standard hazy golden with a white cap.  Flavor is good, strong lemony character combine nicely with the belgian yeast.  Palate is nice and creamy and finishes well with just a taste of banana.  Overall this really got better as it warmed and sticks to style really well.
Sour, Belgian Witbier with hazy golden color, belgian yeast and coriander spice.     Enjoyable wheat wit on draft.

Pours a slight hazy light yellow/golden color with a small head and not really any lacing.  Aroma is slightly sweet and wheat like/  Flavor is light and fruity.  Almost reminds me of champagne on the palate.  Very enjoyable for a wheat beer.

Bottle (thanks Jah Noth).  POurs a golden cloudy color with a light a rocky white head.  Aroma of citrus, yeast, and bread.  Good flavorful notes of bread, yeast, spice, and banana.  A slight try aftertaste and a medium body.... good but not great.

Pours a slightly hazy golden with an average foamy white head.  Aroma if your standard Witbier, just stepped up!  Citrus, spices, banana, wheat and yeast.  Taste is very smooth and refreshing, a great Witbier.
Pours hazy orange/yellow with a small white head. Floral orangey aroma. Taste is dirty lemon, orange, spice. Nothing that stands out. Mediocre.

Contract brewed bottle.

Head is initially small, fizzy, white, fully diminishing.
Body is hazy light yellow.

Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), with a strong note of coriander, note of lemon zest.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic.
Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.

Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.

Yikes, way overdone coriander, bland, simple...what the fark???

I get it ... this is supposed to be another Golden Monkey.  But it does not quite work ...  Hazy gold with almost no head, and a dead mouthfeel that underscores the lack of carbonation.  Slightly off nose.  Taste of wheat and bread, orange, hops, and a bitter finish with good lemon citrus.  Somehow the appearance of the Monkey, the mouth of the Monkey, and the nose of the Monkey are all vastly superior.  The taste of the two is different, and I prefer the sweeter, stronger wheat and malt taste of the Monkey, but there is less reason to pick an obvious favorite on taste.  On the other dimensions the Monkey wins paws down.   Im surprised that my rating comes in so close to the bottom ... maybe the bottle I had did not travel happily to Pennsylvania.  Will try again and rerate if another bottle warrants a change.
RBESG 2005, Hazy pale yellow colour with a white head. Wheaty and spicy aroma with afaint fruityness. Wheaty, light acidic flavor with a spicy finish.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2006 22oz bottle.  Poured hazy and golden, darker than other wits.  Spices immediately waft up from the glass.  A little sour lemon and alcohol presence are also in the nose.  The flavor of this one puts it somewhere in between Hoegaarden and Allagash 10th.  Its stronger than the Hoegaarden, but not as overdone as the Allagash.  The curacao orange peel is a nice touch and gives it a little something extra in addition to the usual wit suspects (lemon, banana, wheat).  Very refreshing and it goes down very easy.

Pours a nice pale, though filtered, with a very nice head. Aroma is rich, fruity, lots of orange, a bit of hops, kinda champagne like. Effervescent palate leads to a super-orangey, spicy, full and sweet taste. My roomate called it over-sweet but I disagree: though it didnt really taste too much like a wit, it was sweet and full and refreshing. A very nice beer, though a bit (read: way too) expensive.
Everything tastes better in the Hamptons. Beautifully spiced nose with ample wheat undercurrent. This was a great summer beer with a thick enough mouthfeel that was almost lush.
Bottle. No head, cloudy dark yellow color. Great aroma, lemon, grassy hops, corriander. Flavor is sweet and lemony. Mild bitterness underneath. Well balanced. Clean finish.
this is a great brew.  Aroma is stronger than the taste.  Nicely spiced not to overpowering - cant taste a the alcohol at all - good for a double white.  definitly buy it again

Version 2005, brassée par sous contrat, Saratoga Springs.  Jaune luminescent, apparence trouble et nuageuse, faible mousse blanche.  Arômes phénoliques de clou de girofle, de blé et de bananes.  Flaveurs de gomme baloune, de bananes, de croûte de pain et de coriandre nous conduisant jusquà un irréversible éclat dalcoolique.  Lalcool, bien présent à chacune des gorgées, refuse dépouser les douces saveurs du blé.  Corps dépaisseur semi mince, on ne ressent pas lépaisseur et la viscosité du blé, encore moins celle du double blé

Bottle:  Courtesy of Shadey via trade.  Aroma is a tad light.  Contains lemon, wheat, and a hint of spice.  Pours a cloudy dull yellow witha  decent white head with good retention.  Flavor has a nice tart lemon presence throughout.  Some wheat is barely detectable.  Finish has a nice combination of spice and bitterness.  Very nice beer.  Aroma is the only thing keeping this out of the 4s for me.

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2006 750 from jimmack. Pours a pale yellow color with a big white foamy head. Quite fizzy. Yeast and light spice, lemony scent. Taste is somewhat dry and unflavorful, light hints of yeast and pepper. 

Draught pint at redbones 7/1/06. Pours a hazy oraneg colro with a crisp white head. Nose is yeasty and lemony with some light spices. Palate is clean and crisp. Flavors are yeasty, lemony, light spiciness with a full body tough to it.
Poured pale yellow, cloudy, with big head, white. Yeast and some spice on the nose. Taste was lacking a bit.

Bottle: Pale straw, quite dull and cloudy, moderate foamy off-white head, superb lacing. &nbsp Floral breadiness on the nose, slight perfume and pepper, but nothing screams witbier. &nbsp I would go towards more of a Blonde with a hint of Witbier. &nbsp Someone soft yet dull spiced tongue. &nbsp Not really sharp like other witbiers. &nbsp Slightly floral, yeasty. &nbsp Again it seems more like a Blonde with hints of Witbier. &nbsp Moderate body, not sharp at all, with a medium mouthfeel. &nbsp Not bubbly at all, somewhat flat on the tongue on the finish. &nbsp Its not bad, but its actually quite boring. &nbsp Thanks for the bottle John!

Sampled at RBESG 2005.Hazy golden, disappearing white head. Yeast and citrus aroma with some light spices and white pepper. Sharp citrusy and orangy flavor. Notes of yeast. Very unbalanced and not very tasty either, I cant believe how overrated it is......
Bottle. Quite tart and refreshing. Orangey, clovey flavours, with some spiceyness in the finish, which im guessing is the coriander. Slight acidic character in the aftertaste, nice one though.

A hazy pale yellow beer with a disappearing white head. The aroma is sweet with notes of wheat and citrus - especially lemon. The flavor is sweet with notes of lemon and wheat. This reminds me a lot of drinking lemonade - very refreshing.

My 2005 bottle records a 7% ABV on the label, but Im not going to quibble about two tenths of a percent.  Comparable to the Abbaye des Rocs Blanche des Honnelles (a double wit in its own right) that I had the other day, this is only slightly lesser because the aroma is much more yeasty, almost covering the wheat scents when aided by the strong lemonade smell.  It looks great - a cloudy straw color with a huge frothy, bubbly white head.  The flavor is a tart caramel/toffee malt, lemony with coriander and white pepper.  It finishes on a mouth watering, sour note.  Wicked wit.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Chicago, IL<font size=-1>

Bottle from Beer Yard.  Poured hazy gold with a sizable frothy, white head.  Big aroma of multiple citrus fruits, hops, some spices.  Tastes somewhat tart, with some bready malts, more hopcit and spices in the finish.

Bottled at RBESG. Cloudy golden. Lactic acid aroma. Nicely rounded mlat character, with pleasant notes of oraneg and curacao. Citric finish. While Ive never been a huge fan of the witbier-on-steroids category I do appreciate this one.

Hazy goldenrod supporting a tall rocky white head with good retention and lots of lacing.  Bright, fruity aroma of citrus, cloves, banana, vanilla and a touch of yeast.  Wonderfully clean and balanced flavor with cloves, pepper, lemon, orange and fresh baked bread all complimenting and supporting one another perfectly.  Mouthfeel was silky and the finish was lightly tart, mildly sweet and very clean.  As an American example of a traditional Belgian Wit, this one hits the mark and sets it quite high.  In fact, I could easily reach for one of these in favor of a Hoegaarden.  It reminded me of Hoegaarden but just slightly crisper.  Excellent beer.
Bottle. Hazy yellow colour with a white head. Sweet wheaty citrus aroma and a light sour wheaty fruity taste. Medium body and a dry finish.

Bottle, from New World Beer. Good nose, Sweet. Wheat, lemon, grass, spice, banana. Hazy golden yellow color, small head, though I poured slow and left sediment for second glass. Alot more in that one. Tart flavors, like aromas. Spice and lemon are prominate. Orange and a little soapy too. Medium body, smooth creamy mouthfeel, tart dry finish. Tasty beer, but not a style I get into usually.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text:
Bottle. RBESG -05. 
Yellow. Classic Wit-profile. Also salty, egg-y feel in aroma and flavour. Very much like Pietra Colomba Blanche. Bit on the malty side. Big on Co2. Bit more sourish than the regular Wit.

Bottle at RBESG Grand Tasting 05. Imperial Wit!! Whatever next! Its just like a normal Wit for a start, but it just goes on and on. Dryer than a standard Belgian White, with the usual lemon and chalk. Good stuff, but no more than 20% bigger than a normal Wit.
Pours hazy pale yellow, with a sparkling white head. Wheaty, spicy clove nose. Acidic, lemon-ish flavour. Sparkling mouthfeel. Quite high carbonation. Somewhat sour finish.
Strong sweet and spicy nose. Milky yellow body, with a small white head. Sourish flavor, with strong notes of yeast and spice.

Bottled @ RBESG2005: Light yellow coloured. Hazy. Small white head. Yeast, citrus, coriander and other wheaty notes in aroma. Flavour as well is somewhat wheaty. Fruits, citrus, spices and some acidic sourness in the flavour. Has a balanced sourness in the end. Is quite  dry and refreshing.

Bottled @RBESG05
Pale hazy yellow, small white head. Wheaty nose. All aspects of witbier are there. Same time sweet, hoppy and sour. Good sour witbier.

Big bottle - no cork and wire but capped.  A fresh and delicious Hoegarden on steroids.  Cloudy orage ale; spices exceptionally well blended and integrated into the brew.  Much less boozy than many other "doubles."
750ml. bottle thanks to Joeec5. Cloudy yellow/gold color with a small white head. Aroma of cloves, bananas, yeast and citrus. Very smooth flavor of banana, cloves, coriander and tart citrus.

22 oz. bottle courtesy of my SecretSanta.  Different label than that in the picture.  From the XXII Reserve series.  Hazy straw pour with a thick bone-white head that leaves some decent lacing.  Aroma is full of bananas, lemons and coriander with some orange peels and cloves.  Decent body.  Not quite as flavorful as I expected from the aroma.  Lots of sweet maltiness compliments the tangy lemony and yeasty flavors.  Some spices in there too.  A peppery finish.  Not too shabby.

On tap at Drafting Room.  Cloudy straw yellow color with a small white head.  Aroma is bananas and citrus.  Flavors are citrus, cloves, bananas, coriander, and a little pepper.  Flavors arent as strong as I had expected from a double wit.  Very easy to drink.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2006 22 oz. bottle. Hazy, deep dull orange-yellow body. Fresh corainder and floral aroma. Clean and pleasant. Medium tartness and sweet for a wit, but thats appropriate with this. This is perfectly sweet. Strong honey notes, with mild lime and mild bitterness. Very nice and better than expected.

Tap at SPH.  Hazy pale straw color with a thin white head.  Aroma of cloves, banana, flowers, and a touch of citrus.  Big flavors with continuation of the clove and banana, some sweetness, some citrus and some alcohol pepperness on the finish.  Light bodied.

Pours a cloudy yellow with a fizzy white head. Another Southampton brew with a interesting sourness to it, giving a nice refreshing taste, awesome for the hot day we were drinking it. Yeast esters and orange peel show nicely in the aroma and finish, very nicely flavored wit, or double wit as is the case here.

Pours a pale dusky straw, with a lingering skim of light head. Aromas of clove, sour apple, wool, and lemon. Delicious burst of grape skin sourness, a little bit of wheat "sparkle" and then an abrupt finish that leaves a chewy sourdough bread taste. Very unusual and very tasty.

Tasted this with Hezron for inspiration while brewing his double-white.

Very citrusy, and teetering toward sour, with a great flecky body, wonderfully suspended yeast and a cakey breadiness. Very orangey, lemony, but not astringent (to me). I wish I had more, but the one bottle from BotW Rochester was it sadly.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: On tap at Delaneys in New Haven.  Poured a cloudy pale white with a white head.  Sweet and spicy aroma.  Taste has a good amount of sweetness and enough spice to add decent complexity.  Some toffee in the finish.  More reminiscent of a belgian wit than a regular belgian ale to me.

07.16.05  Sampled from bomber at BCTC.  Thickly hazedd, near opaque pale straw.  Fleeting head.  aroma is spicy, weeds, corriander, bubblegum, some floral.  Really spiced up flavor but plenty of body to keep the spices from settling out too much on the palate.  Not much alcohol presence from a double anything.  Its a shame to call it double because it would be a fantastic plain old wit.

Bought a bottle of this a couple of years ago and gave to friend that had done so many favors for me. Finally getting to sample at the pub seems the ultimate reward. For some reason I had strange and perhaps unfavorable expectations despite my love of their beers here. Again, nice to be proven wrong. I enjoy a wit, but sometimes the balance leans to far in one direction. Here the balance leans too far in ALL directions and comes out all the better for it. Tangy and tart and more bitter than I would have thought and just perfect for the incredibly muggy weather that NY was experiencing at the time. Pure delight.

(Bottle) Sampled at the Belgium Comes To Cooperstown 2005 in Cooperstown, NY. Pours a cloudy, lemon juice coloured body. Nice banana and yeasty nose. Mildly milky. Very good but a tad weak in flavour.

I need to drink more from this publick house! Another enjoyable offering - a standard wit but with some saison thrown in. Spicy coriander and some citrus zing but a certain funkiness too. Peppery and yeasty flavours and a nice finish. Nice.
hazy yellow.  lemon/lime aroma with coriander, pepper and yeast.  tart citrus, yeast, pepper, and wheaty malt in the flavour.  quite nice.
Bottle: pours gold and cloudy with no real head to speak of.  Smells of bananas and oranges.  Taste is orangey with a lot of spice on the finish.
Hazy light gold, fizzy white head. Pleasant fresh belgian white... orange, banana aroma. Grassy lemon and sweet buttery wheat. Nice and full of good flavor.

Bottle.  Cloudy golden-yellow in colour.  Aroma was quite spicy with lots of coriander, wheat, lemons and oranges.  Spices dominated the flavour, coriander, pepper and citrus all battled to get noticed as well.  A rather yeasty mouthfeel, medium body and high carbonation.  Finishes with a lingering peppery bitterness.  I thought this was a witbier.  It was just a bit too over the top with coriander for my liking but I at least respected its quality.

Wheaty, grainy aroma with lemon / orange citrus flesh and equally light coriander.  Syrupy-sweet pale malt.  Pretty simple flavor, a sweeter bolder wit with a stronger citrus element.  Good mouthfeel.  Thanks to Jason for hauling this back from NY!

Pale gold with a slight haze and bubbly white head.  Aroma is super sweet whole kernel corn and the traditional Belgian Wit characteristics (lemon, coriander, pepper, etc.)  Flavor reaffirms most aroma suspicions, drawing out lemon, orange zest, coriander, cloves, sourdough, pepper and vanilla.  Its like they hit on all the elements that ring my bell with this style.  Bright on the palate; very lemony citric and effervescent.  Cloves, indeed.  Slick and sweet.  Very citrusy.  Big thanks to JCapriotti for sharing!

2005 bottle.  yellow golden color and mostly clear.  thin creamy white head that goes fairly quickly.  aromas of raisins, sweet bready malt, a little spice and orange peel.  yeasty aroma too.  flavor is dry and spicy.  kind of like a lightweight tripel.  a little bit of cuacao flavor, almost lemony too.  mouthfeel is creamy, carbonation is fizzy.  quite refreshing on a hot summer early evening.  finish is dry and tart like a white wine.  nice white peninsulas of lacing on the glass.

Pale yellow color, not to cloudy as the yeast had settled.  Nice white head.  Aroma is malty, sweet and spicy.  Some clove and lemon notes.  I think I also picked up a little barnyard.  Flavor was much like the aroma, a sweet lemon grass with a spice twist.  Dry finish, felt really good on the palate. Thanks to JCapriotti for sharing.

pours a very light champagne looking w/ lots of carbonation and a big frothy well laced white head.  Smells odd wierdly sour and yeasty w/ a touch of dough.  Palate is a little light well coated and lightly carbonated.  Flavor is a touch wour a wierd yeast taste hints of an odd light fruit sweetness and a light touch of alcohol.  Overall pretty good.

muddy yellow pour with a thin white halo of a head.  Straw-like & grassy aroma with evident yeast & pineapple notes & subtle white grape & banana cream and lingering wheatiness.  Tart & lactic characteristics surround grassy & yeasty flavors.  Subtle spicing remains mostly hidden in the tart and yeasty shadows.  Impressive mouthfeel..creamy & full with a lingering tartness and straw-like bitterness.  Quite dry.  Pretty straight forward wit IMO.

750 ml bottle (2005) shared with the scintillating, sensational ClarkVV in his humble abode.  Furious bubbling action erupts from the yeasty core at the center of the still pale golden body, a dark planet at the center of a bright sun...moderately snowy head graces the lip of the glass, lasting forever and providing opaque sheets of lace...butter cookies, tart lemon, vanilla and subtle spices in the effervescent nose...sensuous mouthfeel with a bitter-honeyish floral character, soft and warming with a bit helping of cookie sugar and cookie-dough yeastiness...acidic lemon and sweet orangepeel prominent in the finish...another absolute gem from Phil & company.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2005 2005 bottle provided by and shared with Muzzlehatch, 5/20/2005.  Perfect appearance in my book: huge white head, which lasts forever and provides for tons of lace.  Intense, tiny bubbles, cloudy, goldenrod appearance.  Aroma of coriander, lemon puffs, Belgian yeast, starfruit.  Flavor is coriander bitterness, Belgian yeast, floral hops, lemons, sugar cookies with moderate acidity on the end.  Juicy tangerine finish with a good dose of bubble gum esters.  Fluffy, tingly unfiltered mouthfeel.  A touch of wheat sourness on the end.  Wow.  I approached this and rated it as a witbier (a big witbier).As an addendum, maybe it wasnt the 2005 bottle that I had.  Whatever year it was, it wasnt the garbage Saratoga contract brewed crap.  It was the real, corked stuff brewed by Phil.

First pour withough massive yeast at the bottom of the bottle is cloudy golden with a dissipating egg white head.  Aroma is spicy/yeasty with a touch of hops.  Bit of orange peel and coriander but not as much as some wit bieres.  Flavor improves upon the aroma a bit, IMO.  Definite orange oil, coriander and yeast goodness.  Mouthfeel is a delicate balance of high carbonation, but not too much.  Well done, and probably represents a pinnacle for the style.
Nice rich golden color with a lasting white head.  Light citrus, spice flavor with a dry finish.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2005  Bottle.  Poured cloudy yellow with scents of lemon, wheat, citrus , orange and lime.  Taste is very lemony and sour.  I am struggling to get into this style.  That being said this is the best example so far for my taste.

Thanks to someone at the 3F Darklord release. Pours a light cloudy yellow. Scents of spicy orange, sour grape, and yeast. Flavor is slightly sour with an vinous background.  Refreshing tingle makes it easy to drink.

Sampled inside FFFs.  :).  Appearance was small particles floating in a murky light yellow body.  A white head topped it off.  Aroma was VERY spicy, apple, wheat, yeast, bubblegum, hint of sourness (not infected), oranges.  Flavor is very spicy.  Coriander, wheat, touch of sour apple, touch of bananas.  This has to be one of the best Belgians Ive ever sampled.  Palate is sour, sweet, medium mouthfeel with good carbonation.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2006 Sampled at ratebeer party today, thanks!Cloudy yellow color with a bright white head.  Sweet aroma that had a yeast bite to it.  The taste is sweet with a hint of citrus that blends nicely.  big corriander and green grapes on the nose with a touch of lemon.  flavors shine the lemon component mostly with some metallic notes as well.  Very dry finish.  Very solid for the style and for an american version.  Very clean and tasty.
Fresh, clean, sweet yeasty nose. Cloudy gold . Nice full flavoured . Citrus character is a positive here. Good wheat ,well crafted .
Golden yellow, large white head. Citrus aroma, flavour of citrus and yeast. As others have mentioned, this has a clean and crisp quality that makes it very enjoyable. sampled at Radekfest 05.

Acquired in trade with Eyedrinkale. Poured a medium, cloudy golden color with an averaged sized white head. Aromas of citrus (oranges and lemons), spices and yeast. Tastes of citrus and spices. Nice clean and crisp finish.

Bottle from Eyedrinkale.  Golden yellow in color with a fantastic white head.  Good lacing.  Sweaty and wheat beer aroma.  The slight funky aroma throws me off a little but is pleasing.  A touch of coriander in the nose and flavor but barely at the level of perception.  Crisp.  Refreshing.

bottle, thanks to eyedrinkale for sharing!  by the way, what exactly IS a "double white ale?"  poured a hazy cloudy canary white with tons of foamy white head that stuck to the glass with about 1/4 inch thick lacing.  tons and tons of coriander and other light spices, even a note of sesame.  sublimely dry, spritzy, and light-bodied.  southampton has made a good first impression!

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2007 April 2005. 750 ml corked and caged.  This is the version prior to it being contract brewed. Very hazy cloudy yellow.  Lots of citurs and banana. Bigger than a regular white.  Deliciously smooth flavor.  Very nice from Southampton. 7/4/8/3/17 
June 2006 - 22oz bottle. It is my understanding that this is the contract brewed version. Clear yellow with nice bubbles. Mild aroma of spices, banana, cloves and a bit of alcohol. Not quite as good as I remember. 7/2/6/3/16

Opaque gold colour.  Slight barnyard hint to the bready malt aroma.  A funky take on the style - got to like that.  Appley esters and dusty yeastiness along with that slight leathery note.  I actually didnt get much spice.

Huge yeast aroma, some citrus and plenty of corriander. Hazy yellow, fair sized white head. Flavour is malt, orange, yeast and corriander for days. Well carbonated, light bodied, very drinkable. Delicious! Thank You Shadey.

2005 bottle. Pours a very cloudy yellow gold, with a small white head. Aroma is lemon, spice, and some sour malt. Flavor is lemony, somewhat sour, with yeast as well. Body is a little heavier than expected, but thsat doesnt take away from it at all. The white/wheat style is not my favorite, but this really good.
Yellow white in color, white head. Aroma of lemon and spice, light wheat. Also fairly yeasty. Mild tartness. Light to medium body works well with this beer. Its ok. Thanks Shadey.

Cloudy yellow-white w/ generous, bright white head.  Light, effervescent aroma of yeast, wheat, lemon, orange peel, & coriander. Light, grainy, spritzy feel.  Flavour is yeasty & slightly tart w/  sweet, malty & spicy notes. Quite refreshing.
bottle. hazy white body, generous white head. citrus sour aroma. a fruity, spicey, sour flavourful ale. nice stuff and my first from the brewer.

this is overated. It was a fresh bottle, thanks to Shadey had at Radekfest 05, sample 21. Its sour! On the plus side is the yeasty aroma and cloudy white appearance. But this brewer should have the skill to control sourness. I dont like over-the-top corriander.
Thanks to Shadey for this one.  Yeasty orange/citrus wheat.  The sourness surprised me at first but I grew to like it.  Well spiced with a tart finish.  Nice.

Looked and smelled very similar to a belgian white except the body was fuller and after a whole bottle you feel buzzed.  Creamy white long lasting head on a hazy golden yellow body.  Moderate to high carbonation.  Aroma  of spices, orange, coriander, and lots of phenolics.  Hints of bubblegum as well.  Aroma is slightly similar to thier saison.  Full flavor of smooth wheat, and malt with only a hint of hops in the end for bittering.  Very smooth aftertaste and refreshing for such a strong beer.
UPDATED: FEB 22, 2007 750 ml bottle. Hazy yellow in color with a nice white head. Malty and spicey aroma. Banana notes. Hints of citrus. Sour.  Malty flavor. Refreshing. Interesting.

750 ml bottle. Hazy pale golden, white head. Malty banana and spice aroma, with a touch  of citrus. Malty favor with some spicy banana and cve weiss beer like notes. Not bad and on the refreshing side, but not really my thing.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: 750 mL bottle, corked & caged (2004 version, less than a year old): pours with a generous white, fluffy head that slowly diminishes and eventually dies into nothing but thin, sparse patches.  Starts off extremely clear, light gold  though the second addition of fluid yields a hazy/fuzzy body.  Rich, fruity, spicy aromatics: buttered lemon rinds; soft, elegant yeast, melted bananas, and luscious pears.  A velvety blanket of carbonation entices the soul and sooths the taste buds just in time for them to realize the wonders that surround: tart, green apple pie with a wonderful doughy crust, caramelized banana ice cream, and a dusting or coriander.  A true winner and a great companion to the broccoli risotto and turkey piccata on Valentines Day.

Cask @ CT Real Ale Festival.  Citrusy sour lemons and coriander in the nose with a slight soapiness.  Decent aroma.  Pale straw color and hazy with a large white fluffy head.  Citrus lemon notes to start out turning quite milky and malty in the middle.  Finishing hops are a bit much.  Still decent.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2007 A lactic meringue bobs over full bananas and booming coriander spiciness...Dessert-like milky currents roam about and play off of the acidic touch of citrus fruit towards the end... This is yet another brilliantly brewed ale from Markowski and co, one which is as expressive on tap as it is in the bottle; a rare occurrence for Belgian styles, imho...

Hazy blonde color with yeast in suspension, not much of a head, just a ring of foam around the glass. Aroma of bananas and spices. Flavor of bananas, spices and alcohol with a light acidity. Medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation. So far this one is the one I like the least from Southampton, but still its good and worth tasting.

Mild, sweet banana cream pie with lemon/lime citrus in the aroma and light touches of alcohol. Opaque, pale yellow with decent white head that recedes to ring. Banana, lemon, cream flavours. Light spiciness in the finish. Soft and creamy but perhaps a bit still. Carbonation is low for style. Enjoyable, certainly, but not all I was hoping for. Bottle enjoyed with beerbuzzmontreal, MartinT, Rastacouere and a gang of bierophoux.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2004 Appearance is a bottle-conditioned yeast particles intense cloudy golden. Nicely laced white head never leaves although it could be larger. Aroma surprises at first with its citric and lactic side. This is as zesty as it gets, lime like, passion fruits, spicy ginger, coriander. Very subtle alcohol, cream hints. Nice smell for a wit. Im taken aback by the first sip though. It is quite acid.. once again lactic and citric, this time a bit more in an orangey citrusy way, but it gives the impression to be a yeast affair and doesnt appear like the logical following to the beautiful aroma. Carbonation level is very high, yet its rather smooth and medium bodied. Not as full as a blanche neige or as spicy/weird as a kiuchi to me among my top witbiers, but Ill revisit soon enough to study into this sourness further.  Second sample was less tart, quite citrusy, fluffy. Sometimes reminiscent of a lemonade with big carbonation, biting. I'll leave the score where it's at..

Shared at a tasting with ratebeerians Ernest and Aubrey.

Hazy Yellow.

The aroma was incredible. Easily one of the best smelling beers I have ever come across. Notes of lemon peel, orange, butter toffee and coriander in the nose.

Flavor was more of the same. Notes of lemon, coriander, caramel, butter toffee and orange. This is by far the best wit beer I have ever had.

POP!, goes the cork, and away we pour....cloudy golden hue, beneath a majestic helping of snowy froth, leisurely collapsing to a more modest dimension.
Nose perfectly captures the soul of the wit, the light, breezy nature, mixed with delicate spice, and accompanying citric zest vapors. Easily matches the uplifting aromas of the very best witbiers Ive ever known.
Tangy tartness starts off the taste, giving a cause to pucker and sliding lemony flavor down the tongue. It returns with each additional congress between cup and lip, and each time delivers a serious, even juicy, blast of flavor. Still, lightness remains, and refreshment is the order of the day. Light in body, but with a long, fruity finish, and a uncompromising commitment to flavor. I admire more and more the insistence of the citric feel on the tongue and back down the throat the further I get into this full-size bottle, and the spices are better regarded too, the more I partake. 
Other whites/wits Ive had deliver, then peter out, but not this one, it stays strong from the start and never quits. The flavor is almost palpable, and urges every sip onward. (I had an undesired ale before this, and relish the act of enjoying every taste, rather than plodding through an unexceptionable bore of a beer.)
Magnificent, really. Wish I had more than the one sample, (thanks to sulldaddy!), so I could share among others at picnics, park benches, drive-in movies, motorcycle rallies, kite-flying expeditions, Crimean War re-enactments, Klingon weddings, voodoo ceremonies, hammock testings, effigy burnings...any time really...good beer, perfect for good people, wherever they may be found.

The beer arrived in a 750 ml greenish brown, champagne style bottle with a wire cage and a cork. The beer was included in the BIF 10 box by Lupe of beeradvocate. The cork was quite tight and when pulled out, gave a nice and loud pop. The body was pale yellow in color with some yeast induced cloudiness. The head was quite small in size due to my intitial gentle pour, although a steady stream of bubbles did stay around the entire session. My second pour was more aggressive, and a nice head did fomr at first, but it was not very lasting.  The aroma was very musty and earthy at first, but as the beer breathed fresh air, the fruity scents of banana and orange, and some floral notes came more to the forefront. The taste was delicately light with a lemony, zesty flavor that was perfectly enhanced by spices that tasted like ginger, pepper, and coriander. The alcohol content was very deceptively hidden, and did not get in the way of the refreshing nature of the beer at all. The mouthfeel was light, and just a touch creamy. The aftertaste was dry and warm, thanks to the alcohol and the spices. This 2004 edition is a most delicious take on the style.

Yes it is what it is, that is a delicate style that many cant appreciate.  Light yellow color, looks kind of like a Chardonnay when pour.  Moderate white head.  Aroma is very yeasty and sweet.  Flavor is sweet,sweet,sweet.  This is a fantastic summer brew.  Finish is sweet and then tart.  Thanks Secret Santa!

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2004 Tasted at the GA 14% gathering. Thanks to Wunderbier for the chance to sample this one!
Looks like a witbeer. Frothy white head, on a light yellow cloudy body.
Fizzy, sweet lemon aroma and taste with a tart, dry finish. Not bad, but not a style that impresses me much.

Pale, cloudy yellow, thin white head. cereal, oatmeal aroma. Very spritsy mouthfeel. Raisin, oats, and lemony finish. Note of grapes, flowers, and other citrus fruiits, as well. Very entertaining and refreshing. I liked this one a lot.

Toasted bread (M); spicy hops (L); bananas (just like gerber banana baby food), corriander?  Pale yellow with large particles.  Foamy white head.  Moderately sweet, moderately acidic flavor becomes a moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter finish.  Medium-light body, oily/watery texture, fizzy carbonation.  The bottom line is: banana food taste would make this hard to drink in large quantities.
WCCII: Light cloudy blond beer with a medium head. Light toffee aroma. In the taste we have fruit and toffee. An interesting beer.
Slightly sweet citrus aroma.  SLightly sweet malt body that is nicely balanced.  An enjoyable Belgian.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2005 Cloudy and deep yellow-orange with a big white head. Spicy and dry nose was yeasty, clean and enticing. Lively, spritzy carbonation. Coriander and bitter orange flavors/aromas were nice, but they were somewhat subdued. Sweet malt flavors (honey-like and bready). Wholesome and earthy. A little too sweet; not spicy enough; and not bitter enough.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2008 Classic Belgian White with a cloudy yellow color and nice sized egg shell colored head. Aroma was both peppery and oranges. Taste was yeasty, sweet and effervescent, which reminded me of the old Celis White. Lingering peppery sweet taste with mellow sour lemons. Big floaties on the bottom of the glass. Nice lacing throughout.

2004.  Hazy golden body with a thick, fluffy white head.  Sweet, fruity aroma full of lemon grass, orange peel, bananas, coriander, clover honey and light, sweet malt.  The body is elegantly light and refreshing after an 80 degree day.  The sweet fruit and subtle spice become more and more prevalent in the flavor.  The playfulness of the fruit and spice is well received by the tongue.  The finish adds a light hoppiness to keep things from being boring.  Another winner from Phil Markowski and the brewers at SPH.

Medium hazy gold yellow blond with smallish white head. Intriguing sour dough grain and caramel toffee aroma. Low sweetness thin tending towards watery body. Evident spices and soft grainy malt flavours. Light low sweetness medium bitter finish.

Nice hazy orange color with a little layerof a head. Big banana and vanilla nose. The Banana and Vanilla is accomplished by apples in taste - also oranges. Light peppery aftertaste - nutmeg. Thank you so much Joe and Jen for this great gift!

2004 bottle Vintage, Sampled April 2004As I pour this beer it generates a thick, white, frothy head.  The beer itself is a murky yellow orange color.  Aromas of bready yeastiness, lemon zest, and orange waft from my glass.  As I take my first sip I note that this beer is nice and refreshingly light bodied.  It finishes with an appealing acidic tartness, which is a great foil for the flavors that are in the front of this beer.  There is a definite lemony/ orange character, and it is joined by a light coriander note.  The carbonation reinforces the invigorating zing that is found in the finish.The acidity in this is quite wonderful, nothing like a Lambic or a Flemish Sour, but it is here, and it is quite welcome.  I really like this beer, of course I am a sucker for Wit beers.  This beer finishes with a bit of astringency.  This beer is straight forward, yet complex at the same time, refreshing yet contemplative.
Aroma is a sweet buttery wheat. Flavor is sweet buttery caramel wheat with a slight spicy hop kick. Nice butterscotch aftertaste.

Thanks to argo0 for bringing this to When Continents Collide 2! Very clouded blond with lots of floaties suspended in the body. Very carbonated. Strong spice and citrusy aroma. Effervescent body with a citrus fruit and wheat/yeast taste. Lighter spice notes as well. Seemed like a Belgian wit, almost. Good beer nonetheless.
(WCC2) Hazy straw body with big white head.  Aroma is medium sweet, lemon, wheat.  Taste is mild sweet, lemon, wheat.  Light medium body.  Seems a bit off, perhaps too tart?
Hazy gold, fluffy white head and slight lacing.  Citrus and some spice in the aroma, some yeast as well.  Vanilla, orange peel, and some slight spice in the taste.  Alcohol at the very end.

Looks like the 2004 version has a bit more alcohol, listed at 7%. Cloudy straw color with a voluminous white lasting head. Lots of citrus in the nose, along with some tropical fruits, light yeast (chalk) and coriander.  A few islands of lace.  Silky and spritzy at the same time. It does seem to stick a bit in the back of the mouth. Lots of nuances to this one. Starts quite dry with wheat and mild cider. Mid swallow has the mild dry spice. the finish has a sweet fruity malt flavor that lingers to pure peach syrup with a hint of malt. Pairing this with a fresh fruit tart or waldorf salad would be heavenly. Thanks to austinpowers I have had a few of this brewery's fares and they all seem to be well thought-out and made. I thought about setting this one for a bit, but I am glad I didn't. I think the yeast may do some funky things in this one if it sat for a long time.

Thanks Jen and Joe! Excellent beer - complex, full, and interesting. Starts with a very Belgian-like nose of grains and yeast. Hazy pale orange color with some head retention at first. Snap, crackle, burp! - this stuff is so fizzy you hear it perculating in the glass. Fine blend of vanilla, muscat, pepper, orange and yeast flavors in the middle haunt the late arriving spiced aftertaste. Full, creamy body and a great balance
Pours a cloudy golden colour with a huge frothy head. Aroma of citrus and yeast. Flavour is sweet, wheat, yeast, orange peel and a bit spicy. Not really a Witbeer, but a fine belgian ale.
Golden hazy w thin long lasting bubble white head, nose mostly wheat and yeast. Lots of yeast in the taste sweet and fruity, the burps are very sweet and pleasant.

Atlanta Gathering: Cloudy golden hue with fluffy white head and some lace. The aroma hints of coriander, caradmom, wheat and other grains, touch fruity sour, and dusty yeast esters. The taste has a wonderful balance between spices, sweet malt and light refreshing bitterness. The wheat character is noticed throughout the tasting with a quick hit of citris thrown in. The aftertaste has a lingering bitterness to it. Medium-bodied with a soft but lively mouthfeel. A very nice witbier, very traditional and enjoyable. Recommended.

Pours a pale hazy golden with a white head.  Well balanced, enticing spicy and Belgian yeasty aroma.  Body is mildly spicy and bitter, very dry and light in flavor.  This seems like it would make a perfect refresher on a hot summer day.  I don't know if I'd call it a double, because it seems more like a 1.5X, but still a very unique and enjoyable beer.  Thanks to goldtwins for bringing this to the Atlanta gathering.

This is something I'd like to try my hand at. I love witbiers and my wife enjoys them as well and this is quite simply an excellent witbier made with a bit more body (although not heavy) and just a hint of alcohol presence. The body is a little darker than the average witbier and a bit heavier (although if you've had Dogwood Summer, you've got an idea about it). The coriander and orange peel aromas meld nicely with the yeasty esters and phenols and the alcohol peeps through just enough that you know it's there, but not enough to slap you in the face and say "look at me! I'm big!" Great beer. I'd love to make a trip to this brewery's brewpub.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2004 An excellent witbier.  Pours a oily golden color with a huge egg white head.  Spicy in the nose, with some very nice rentention and great lacing.  Mouthfeel is slightly thin, but the flavor is wonderful.  Creamy and acidic, with lots of orange, corriander, grapefruit and pineapple, and maybe a little bit of honey sweetness at times.  Nice and tart.  Re-rate:  Banana baby food, with some zingy citrusy notes, coconut, light plastic, pineapple and some granny smith apples.
Cloudy yellow appearance. Taste is sour with lemons, bananas, and grapefruit. This is a good representation of a Belgian white, however I don't really seem to enjoy the style very much.
This is a good white Belgian Ale.  Spicey, coriander, and fruity flavor.  Finishes creamy, smooth, and clean.

The early beer discovery days started with Hefe's and Wit's, so I'm still a bit partial.  This beer was fantastic!  The picture on the left is exactly what you get, maybe a bit more hazy though.  Complex nose of apricot, orange, pear, pineapple, and  a touch of pepper and corriander.  Taste is very similar to smell.  Had some fresh bread, doughy, fruity, spicy thing working for me.  Loved it.  Let the beer warm up a bit first though.  That's when it really shines.  Medium to full bodied and simply one of the best Wit's I have had in some time.  My wife, who is not a huge beer fan, asked when we're getting more?  I was shocked to hear her say that!  Anyway, worth the effort to get this.  If you like this style, you can't go wrong here.

Not my style, but a damn fine beer nonetheless!
Very pale, hazy pear-colored ale. Large, fizzy, white head. Great retention.
Very spicy. Pineapple, apricot, orange peel, coriander and pear in the aroma. Bisquity as well.
High ABV is well hidden in the flavor and aroma.
Spicy and fruity. Very refreshing with notes of orange blossom honey.
Full-bodied with a fizzy mouthfeel. Sweet, tangy finish.

Hues of lemon and tangerine, it's lightly yeasty with a lot of saison, less coriander than is typical, broadened as it warmed, delicious, a bunch like an abbey. Lightly tangy throughout. The creaminess really kicks in as the cool effervescence ebbs with warming. A very tasty beer -- don't let the style on the label dissuade you!

Honey colored with a thin clinging white head. Very slight floral nose and a medium/light body. A subtle beer that may have suffered slightly from too much restraint. Mouthfeel is excellent leaning towards a full creamy texture. At first this beer seemed lightly spiced and lacking in the tartness I like in wits but as it warmed it really started to shine.

I must give a big thanks to herbjones for sharing this one with me. This pours a hazy yellow gold color with a white meringue head. There's absolutely no orange peel taste in here, but as the beer warms the spiciness comes out. It is very creamy on the palate & is a good hot weather beer.

I thought this one was a little strong.  And it wasn't all that white looking, so I felt duped cuz I had anticipated a Belgian Witbier.  Oh well.  As a Belgian Ale, it was somewhat spicy and otherwise relatively unremarkable.
A pale yellow color and cloudy. A sour and floral spice flavor with wheats and yeast.

Yuck, Yuck, Yuck. Pure rotton wheat or as 
Tonya says baby banana puke. Yellow in color and cloudy.
Cloudy straw color. Bananas. Citrus. Corriander. Interesting use of a more phenolic yeast with a Wit. Some spiciness. Creamy. Give it six months and I bet it will be nice!
Very cloudy, bright yellow color.  The finsih was a little too alcoholic, although it is a similar to the Belgain Trippels in flavor, if not the full-bodiedness.  Good, but not great.

This was a very interesting take on a belgian ale.  Like a white beer on steroids.  Lots of spice in the flavor.  Mildly alcoholic.  Lemony and zesty.  Mild sweetness as well.  Peppery.  Nice lacing, to boot.  Strange palate, though.  Not a great beer, but still pretty good.
(bottle RAF 03) Big head. VERY spicy aroma with loads of coriander. Nice spicy flavor. Maybe a bit thin. Pretty good for a style i don't love.
Light and yeasty aroma with a mild dash of spice. Piss yellow color with little white head.  More spice than fruit comes through in the taste along with yeast, and also has a lingering aftertaste.

Cloudy, yellowish white. Nose of coriander with hints of oranges and apricots. Flavor is quite sweet, with aforementioned notes of coriander/orange/apricot blending together nicely into a tangy pleasure. Some alcohol presence noted, but not badly.
Spicy, cinnamon, what aroma. Buttery, yeasty, bread-like wheat malt flavor, hints of pepper/spice, orange and light coriander. An aggressive white, very smooth ,one of the better I have tried.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2005 Hazy straw.  Minimal white foam.  Phenolic aroma, alongside butter, leaf, straw, heavy yeast notes, and faint pepper traces.  Medium bodied.  Light carbonation.  Starts fairly interesting with light leafy hop notes, followed by notes of mint.  Beautiful transition to a long pronounced pale malt, buttery, and coriander finish.  Stunningly good.
